entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction

This is the first part of a multi-part series designed to walk you through the end-to-end setup and usage of Joule Studio. In this part, we'll focus on provisioning—laying the foundation for a successful Joule Skill development journey.

Whether you're an architect, developer, or business process expert, this guide will help you correctly configure your SAP BTP environment, set up entitlements, and prepare your subaccount for secure and scalable development with Joule.

What is Joule Studio?

Joule Studio enhances the productivity and business impact of Joule, SAP's AI copilot. It is equipped with powerful capabilities designed to extend Joule’s intelligence to align with your organization’s specific processes, terminology, and needs.

Key Features:

  • Develop new Joule Skills for executing tailored, deterministic tasks aligned with business operations.
  • Manage and deploy updated skill versions to ensure continuous adaptability and improvement.
  • Define user access and permissions, ensuring the right teams can execute or administer the skills securely.
  • Seamlessly integrated with SAP Build, Joule Studio benefits from SAP's low-code/pro-code environment powered by generative AI.

SAP Joule Studio Architecture

 

Business Challenges and SAP's Solution

Business Challenges

  • Fragmented user experiences across enterprise applications.
  • Time-consuming manual processes, such as fetching business data.
  • Limited customization in out-of-the-box AI tools.
  • Technical complexity in onboarding automation tools.

SAP's Solution: Joule Studio with SAP Build

SAP addresses these challenges through:

  • Low-code development with SAP Build for quick customization.
  • Joule Booster to simplify provisioning and trust setup.
  • Joule Skills to extend the AI assistant with custom logic and backend integration.
  • BTP & IAS integration for secure, scalable access control.

 

Quotas

When using Joule Studio the following quotas apply.

A quota represents the numeric quantity that defines the maximum allowed consumption of a resource. In other words, how much of a service plan you're entitled to use.

You can find the quotas listed for Joule Studio below.

 

Action tasks

Connection timeout

1 minute

Time to establish the connection with the remote host.

 

Socket timeout

3 minutes

Maximum period between two data packets.

 

Total execution time

4 minutes

Total time an action task can execute.

 

Request body size

512 KB

 

 

Response content size

100 KB

 

Known Limitations

When using Joule Studio, note the following limitations:

  • The authorizations defined at environment level support users or user groups. Projects can be shared with a maximum of 10 user groups with execution or admin rights, or 5 users, and cannot be shared with a combination of user groups and users.
  • Deploying Joule skills to a shared environment in a production tenant can take up to 30 minutes.
  • It is possible to release and deploy a project in which no triggerable skills have been defined. However, this can lead to errors during the deployment.
  • When you use processes and automations from SAP Build Process Automation it is only possible for Joule Skills to start the processes or automations. Results from process and automations can not be integrated into the Joule skill flow.
  • If you type in values for Inputs or Outputs for your Joule skill and delete these manually, the value is missing but you can still release your project. The missing parameter can lead to errors when you run your Joule skill.
  • If you enter just a space, for example " ", in an input or output parameter, you can release your project but this can lead to errors during deployment.
  • When using a data type as input, if you use object binding to map to different fields, such as input and output parameters from other steps, this could lead to errors when you launch your Joule skill in Joule.
  • If you change permissions in a shared environment, you need to undeploy and redeploy the projects that have been deployed to the environment

Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure the following:

  • The SAP Build - build-default plan is available in your Global Account.

 

  • The Joule entitlement is assigned in your Global Account.

 

  • Your IAS tenant is automatically discovered in the System Landscape of your BTP Global Account.

Joule Studio supports the following data centers*:

Region Name

Region

Infrastructure Provider

Application Identifier

Subprocessor Region

Australia (Sydney)

AP10

Amazon Web Services (AWS)

das-application!b36397

* Subject to the availability of Joule Base and SAP Build.

 

Provisioning Setup

  • Create a Subaccount in a supported region and subscribe to SAP Build.

 

  • In the subaccount’s Trust Configuration, connect your IAS tenant via OpenID Connect (Joule does not support SAML).

 

  • Disable the Default Identity Provider for login.

 

  • Launch the Joule Booster from the Global Account:

 

 

    • Select your subaccount.

 

 

    • Choose SAP Build Process Automation under capabilities.

 

    • Add the SAP Build system using the build-default plan.

 

    • Complete the wizard by clicking Finish.

 

  • Once complete, navigate to System Landscape → Formation.

 

  • In your subaccount:
    • Create the Joule Admin Role Collection, add all Joule roles, and assign your IAS user.

 

 

 

    • Create the ProcessAutomationAdmin Role Collection similarly.

 

 

In Part 2 of this series, we will dive into developing a custom Joule Skill—adding actions, inputs, and defining the skill logic using SAP Build.

Conclusion

With Joule Studio, businesses can extend SAP Joule's AI capabilities to address their unique operational needs—quickly and efficiently. From provisioning and configuration to skill development and testing, SAP provides a comprehensive framework that’s both powerful and secure.

By building custom Joule Skills within SAP Build, enterprises unlock new opportunities for automation, accelerate digital transformation, and empower users to achieve more with less complexity. Joule is not just an AI assistant—it’s your intelligent productivity partner.

entry.title: Complete Guide to SAP Desktop Agent: Installation, Errors, and Resolutions
entry.content:
In this blog, I’ve referenced SAP Blogs, SAP Developer Tutorials, and included relevant images to support the steps. I've documented all the errors I encountered during the setup of the SAP Desktop Agent in both the Production and Quality VMs, along with the resolutions that worked for me.
Please note that error scenarios may vary depending on your environment. If you come across any other issues, feel free to share them in the comments, I’ll do my best to help!

Install and Set Up Desktop Agent 3 | SAP Tutorials

Install Desktop Agent and Manage Updates | SAP Help Portal

First you need  Access to a SAP BTP tenant with SAP Build Process Automation

The Desktop Agent 3 is an on-premise component of SAP Build Process Automation that is installed locally on user desktops. It executes automation projects that launch and run applications of various kinds, reads information from screens, enters data, clicks options, and processes data.

Manually means open this link SAP Development Tools go into the last of page Scroll down to SAP Process Automation: Desktop Agent 3 for Trial and install the sap  desktop agent from there

                             

When you click on "Go to RBSC Portal," it will prompt you to log in. You need to enter the user credentials of someone who has S-user access. After a successful login, you will see a screen like this.

Then click on add new user,

Please make sure you assign the ProcessAutomationAdmin role when you subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation in your BTP account. If you do not do so you will not be able to add a user.

 

 

 

Go to Download Page

Open file path

You can open the file with administrator rights, and install the service, only if your use case requires it. For example, using the agent in unattended mode in production.

When you are running automation in unattended mode in production or quality vm, you must install the desktop agent as a service.

Right click and run as administrator

I was setting this Desktop Agent in my production VM, so I want to install this as per machine not for current user only.

 

 

 

Errors you can face while registering the agent with your tenant:

  1. Registration failed because we couldn't get the access token from the tenant.

Go to tenant, add tenant:

 

 

After saving, when you click on Activate, if it shows "Connecting" for 1 to 2 minutes after entering your login credentials, then navigate to the History tab and click on Events. If you see an error stating that the registration failed because we couldn't get the access token from the tenant.

 

 

 

Resolution

Add "websocketChoice": "wsProxy" in the configuration file when Desktop Agent version is 3.19.56 or higher.

Follow the following steps:

  1. Install Agent 3.19.56 or Higher
  2. Shutdown Agent
  3. Open the following folder: C:\Users\YourUser\AppData\Roaming\SAPDesktopAgent\Store
  4. Edit the file config.json, at the end of the file (just after the "isTenantCentralizationDone": true,) add the following line "websocketChoice": "wsProxy".
    • Notice that the comma should be added after "isTenantCentralizationDone": true

 

3401479 - Error Message: "The registration failed because we couldn't get the access token from the tenant." | SAP Knowledge Base Article

 

2. Health check is Not Successful Error

For this error, you need to refer to the relevant SAP Note and the solution provided by SAP.

3538761 - Healthcheck is Not Successful Error Seen in Desktop Agent When Connecting to Tenant in SAP Build Process Automation - SAP for Me

 

 

You should reach out to your VM infra team and share the resolution details with them, as the solution needs to be implemented in the VM.

{

In my case, the infra team said that the SSL inspection opens all files before downloading, checks what is inside, then re-encrypts and tags them as "good."

The problem is that when this action is performed, the certificate of the package is changed from (for example) the SAP certificate to the ZIA (Internet Access) certificate, and for some processes, this is not acceptable.

We had to filter out these URLs from SSL inspection, and after these changes it started working.

}

3. Desktop Agent was getting disconnected after 20-30 minutes when I disconnected from the VM.

And the desktop agent gets disconnected.

According to SAP, this is expected behavior, when a user session is logged out, the Desktop Agent will be disconnected.

 However, earlier when I was disconnecting from the VM, the Desktop Agent used to get disconnected after 20–30 minutes.

This behavior was not normal, as the Desktop Agent is expected to remain active as long as there is an active user session in the VM.

After receiving the response from SAP, I communicated with my infra team and explained that when I disconnect from the VM, the user session should not be logged off after 20 to 30 minutes — the session needs to remain active.

This is important because the SAP Desktop Agent is dependent on the user session. As long as the user session remains active, the Desktop Agent will also stay connected and continue working.

Based on this, the infra team made a change in the GPO settings, and since then, it has been working correctly.

Q: When I was disconnecting from the VM, why was the user session getting logged off after 20 to 30 minutes, not immediately?

A: When you disconnect from a VM without logging off, Windows keeps the session in a disconnected state.
By default, Group Policy settings may define a timeout period after which disconnected sessions are automatically ended.
This is usually set to conserve system resources or due to company security policies.

In your case, the system likely had a default timeout of 20 to 30 minutes configured, which caused the user session to log off automatically after that time.

How is it working after this GPO change shown in the image?

The GPO setting you have applied for is:

  • Set time limit for disconnected sessions is Enabled
  • End a disconnected session is set to Never

This means disconnected sessions will no longer be automatically ended, regardless of how long they remain disconnected.


As a result, the user session remains active even after disconnecting the VM.
Since the SAP Desktop Agent relies on an active user session, it now continues running without getting disconnected.

Precautionary Measure When the Desktop Agent Gets Disconnected in the VM:

 So, in the Production or Quality VM, if the SAP Desktop Agent gets disconnected due to any reason, you can receive an alert notification within 5 minutes. This allows you to manually check and quickly resolve the issue.

To enable this, you need to configure an Alert Handler in your SAP Build Process Automation Lobby.
As part of this setup, you must also create an SMTP destination in your BTP Cockpit to handle email notifications.

  • Alert Handler for the Agent Disconnected Event | SAP Help Portal
  • Configure an SMTP Mail Destination | SAP Help Portal               

Steps to test the SMTP destination in SAP Build Lobby:

Step 1: Go to SAP Build Lobby

 

Step 2: Select Control Tower

 

 

 

Step 3: Click on Mail Server

 

 

Step 4: Click on Send Test Mail

Step 5: Click Send Test Mail

 

  • 3597116 - Logging off a Virtual Machine disconnects the Desktop Agent - SAP for Me
  • 3531931 - Unlocking VM Session for Unattended Automation in SAP Build Process Automation - SAP for Me
  • 3208410 - "Can't unlock" error while running unattended bot in a Virtual Machine - SAP for Me

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 2: Developing and Deploying a Joule Skill
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In Last Part of this series, we covered how to provision Joule Studio in your SAP BTP Landscape. Now that your system and entitlements are in place, it's time to dive into the hands-on development of your first Joule Skill and learn how to deploy and test it.

This guide walks through creating a custom skill, integrating backend actions, configuring responses, and deploying it for use in your SAP environment.

 

Develop and Deploy Joule Skills

Step-by-Step Development

  • Launch the SAP Build Lobby and log in using your IAS credentials.

 

  • Click Create, then select the Joule Skill tile.

 

 

  • Enter a name, description, and define the functionality of your skill.

 

  • After project creation:
    • Click Create again and select Joule Skill.

 

    • Add actions, processes, conditions, or automations.

 

    • For example, add an action to retrieve Business Partner data from S/4HANA PCE.

 

 

  • Configure:
    • An environment variable for the destination.

 

    • Any mandatory input parameters.
    • Skill inputs from user input if needed.
  • Add a Send Message component:

 

    • Use the Message Editor.

 

    • Multiple message type is available, I am choosing List type and map the results from the action response.

 

 

 

 

  • Save, release, and deploy the skill to your environment.

 

 

  • Go to the environment to test the skill.

 

 

  • Launch the standalone Joule interface, interact with the skill, and review logs as needed.

 

 

 

 

Conclusion

In this part, you’ve taken the next big step in your Joule Studio journey—developing and deploying your first custom Joule Skill using SAP Build. From designing the skill logic and integrating backend actions, to configuring dynamic responses and testing in a real environment, you've now seen how intuitive and flexible Joule Studio can be.

This hands-on experience demonstrates how easily you can create intelligent, AI-powered automations that directly serve your unique business needs—all without writing complex code..

entry.title: Automate Offer Letter Generation by using SAP BTP Process Automation
entry.content:
In this blog, I am going to show you that how to automate the generation of offer letter using SAP BTP Process Automation.
Overview of the Automation Process
This automation process involves opening a Word file template, replacing placeholders with the new joinee's details, saving the customized offer letter, and sending it via email to the respective candidate.

First of all, we should have a offer letter template saved as docx file in our desktop as below :





Create a new automation project
Log into SAP Build Lobby.
Click create -> Automated Process->Automation and click on next

Name your project ‘OfferLetterGenerator’.
Provide a short description  “Bot to generate offer letter”.

Click on ‘Review’ and then ‘Create’.

Designing the Automation Bot
In the automation section, click create -> automation and give the agent version

name it ‘Offer Letter Generator’ and add description as ‘ An automation which generates offer letter and send email to respective candidate’.


Click on create.

Click on setting option, go to dependencies and  click on add -> Add a business process project dependency, then add ‘outlook SDK’  and ‘word SDK' ( as in this automation we are going to use WORD and OUTLOOK so it is necessary as it makes available the different activities related to that particular software in our activities section )

Similarly add word SDK.


The key input parameters for this automation are:

  • companyName
  • candidateName
  • canAddress
  • currentdate
  • post
  • technologyunit
  • city
  • salary
  • joiningDate
  • HrManagerName
  • hremail
  • HrPhoneNumber
  • senderemail
  • receiveremail

So go to Input/Output section and create those input parameters as like : -

Similarly add all other input parameters as well.

Now, Add these activities by drag & drop from the tools section : -
i) Open Word Instance
ii) Open Document(Word)
iii) Replace All(Word)
iv) Save As(Word)
v) Close Document (Word)
vi) Close Word Instance
vii) Open Outlook Instance
viii) Send Email (Outlook)
ix) Close Outlook Instance

In Open Document (Word) activity, in parameter section add the path of offer letter template in ‘documentPath’ field.

 

And in 'replace all (word)' activity give the placeholder and value name in old string and new string section for each detail which is needed to be replaced ,
as like this:


Similarly do for all placeholders.

After that, in Save As (Word) activity set the filepath as ‘ "{Folderlocation}\\" + Step0.candidateName + "_Offer_Letter.docx" ’ ( so that the new offer letter word file generated is saved as that respective candidate name).

 

Now go to Send Email (Outlook) activity, and add parameters as,
from -> senderemail
to -> receiveremail
Subject -> Letter of Joining
Body -> "Please find the offer letter attached and report to the assigned location on exact date."
In attachment section click on custom data and add string value as the file location as
 ‘ "{Folderlocation}\\" + Step0.candidateName + "_Offer_Letter.docx" ’


Finally, Run the automation and fill the details in input fields : -

then click on test and you will find that a word file of offer letter with candidate name created at the folder location and a mail is sent to respective receiver. 

Benefits of this automation: -

  • Automating the offer letter generation process significantly reduces the time required to create and send offer letters.
  • It minimizes the risk of human error, ensuring that all details are correctly filled in.
  • The use of a standardized template ensures that all offer letters maintain a consistent format and tone.

entry.title: SAP Discovery Center Mission: Build custom Joule skills for SAP & non-SAP systems using Joule Studio
entry.content:
SAP is on a mission to make Joule, its generative AI assistant, ubiquitous across the entire product portfolio - from S/4HANA and SuccessFactors to BTP and SAP Build. SAP ships Joule with a rich set of out-of-the-box skills to fetch data, transact, navigate, automate tasks, and deliver contextual insights through natural language. But many organizations need more: tailored responses, industry-specific workflows, and integration with custom systems etc.,

That’s where Joule Studio comes in. With Joule Studio, businesses can build custom Joule skills and agents for both SAP and non-SAP systems, empowering users with AI-driven capabilities tailored to their unique processes.

Note: Joule Studio is part of SAP Build. With SAP Build, you can now create low-code/no-code apps, processes, approvals, automations, and decisions. It also supports pro-code development using Fiori, CAP, and mobile frameworks. You can design compelling user experience sites; all natively infused with Generative AI to enhance productivity and accelerate time-to-value.

What is Joule Studio?

Joule Studio is a developer-friendly environment that enables both professional developers and business technologists to create, manage, and deploy AI-powered skills and agents. Whether it’s fetching data from S/4HANA or triggering a multi-step process in ServiceNow, Joule Studio simplifies it - with little to no code.

This blog focuses on the SAP Discovery Center mission dedicated to building Joule skills using Joule Studio. (Agent development is currently in beta, with general availability planned for Q4 2025. Stay tuned for a follow-up blog on that).

Why Joule Studio?

Joule Studio enables you to:

  • Build AI skills - atomic tasks triggered by natural language (e.g., “Show open purchase orders”).
  • Develop AI agents - multi-turn, intelligent assistants that manage complex workflows (e.g., onboarding an employee or exception handling in order processing, finding weather trends or tariff changes and suggesting pricing changes).

Key Features of Joule Studio:

Feature

Description

Visual Skill Builder

No-code/low-code UI to define intents, logic, and response formats

Agent Framework

Design multi-step, multi-intent workflows with skills, memory, and branching logic

SAP Integration

Connect to BTP services, OData APIs, CDS views, workflows, and SAP applications.

Non-SAP Integration

Connect with external APIs like ServiceNow, MS Teams, and Salesforce

Human-in-the-loop

Include approval steps or manual interventions within agent workflows.

Security & Identity

Uses SAP BTP’s security model for authentication, role management, and access control.

Multichannel Deployment

Deploy skills and agents across SAP Start, SAP Build Work Zone, MS Teams, and more

Deep Dive: Joule skills:

Joule skills are components of an advanced AI model designed to execute atomic operations - single, predefined tasks that run independently and deterministically within a conversation. Joule Skills provide a fast, structured, and reliable way to automate repetitive business tasks and retrieve data within SAP systems. They eliminate manual work, reduce errors, and improve efficiency, allowing users to focus on more strategic activities.

Key Capabilities of Joule skills:

  • Deterministic Execution – Skills perform predefined actions with fixed inputs and outputs.
  • Natural Language Understanding – Joule accurately interprets user intent regardless of phrasing.
  • Context Awareness – Skills only trigger when contextually relevant, based on user role and interaction history.
  • Unified Automation – SAP-provided and custom skills coexist in a single productive Joule instance.

Key Characteristics of Jouke skills:

  • Intent-driven – Each skill is initiated by natural language input.
  • Composable – Skills can be combined to create intelligent workflows.
  • Low-code – Built using tools like:
    • Condition Editor – define logic based on data
    • Formula Editor – manipulate and compute values
    • Skill Parameters – manage input/output variables
    • Message Format Editor – structure output for display
  • Extensible – Easily customized for unique business processes
  • Action Projects – Enable connectivity to remote systems (e.g., S/4HANA, Ariba, or Northwind) via APIs

Ready to Get Hands-On?

Joule Studio is shaping up to be one of the most significant releases in SAP Build in 2025. We know many of you are eager to dive in, experiment, and build your own AI skills.

To help you get started, our team has created and published a SAP Discovery Center Mission: Build custom Joule skills for SAP and non-SAP systems using Joule Studio.

This guided mission walks you through every step - validating prerequisites, setting up your environment, enabling necessary services, configuring connectivity to systems like S/4HANA, and building and testing your custom skills in Joule.

 

You'll walk away with a working Joule skills project featuring multiple skills - a solid foundation for building enterprise-ready, intelligent AI assistants.

So, what are you waiting for? 

🚀Go to Build custom Joule skills for SAP and non-SAP systems using Joule Studio in SAP Discovery Center and start your mission. We’ll be cheering for you.

Happy ‘Build’ing! 😊

Kudos to my co-authors @sdavid & @CharleneZ. Thanks to Joule Studio product management & engg team for early access.

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 3: Integrate Joule Skills with Work Zone Sites
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In Last Part of this series, we covered how to create a skill, consume public APIs and deploying it for consumption.

In this guide, we will walk through the process of creating a custom skill related to a specific application (a CAP based Fiori application in this case), deploying it, and finally enabling Joule in SAP Build Work Zone.

Develop and Deploy Joule Skills for a Custom Application.

Step-by-Step Process:

  • Create a Destination in SAP BTP Subaccount where Joule Studio is subscribed – pointing to the endpoint of your CAP service
  • Make sure sap.processautomation.enabled is set to true in additional properties for it to be consumed in SAP Build

 

 

  • Add Destination into the Control Tower section

 

  • Select Action section and Click Create to start a new action project.

 

  • Select SAP Cloud Application Programming Model as your action will have to point to a SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Service.

 

  • This lists down all possible service calls available

 

  • Select required endpoint and configure it.

 

 

  • Click Create, then select the Joule Skill tile and follow steps as per the previous blog in series - Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - P... - SAP Community

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • Save, release, and deploy the skill to your environment.

 

  • If you want your skills to be accessible globally from the work zone site, enable the shared environment property. Else, these skills will be available only on a standalone assistant.

 

 

Integrate Joule with Work zone

  • Under Formations in Global Account level, Click Include systems and select SAP Build Work Zone from required Subaccount

 

  • Select both Enable Capability Deployment and Enable Joule Icon in Integrated System

 

  • Complete the wizard by clicking Include

 

  • Once complete, navigate to System Landscape → Formation.

 

 

  • Login to your work zone

 

  • Select Required Site and click on Settings icon

 

  • You should now be seeing property to Enable/Disable Joule. Enable the Joule property.

 

 

  • Open your site and you should be seeing the Joule Icon at the top

 

  • Test your deployed skills by prompting your query

 

 

 

 

Conclusion:

By integrating Joule Skills with SAP Build Work Zone, you bring intelligent assistance directly into your business applications. This part of the series demonstrated how to connect a CAP-based Fiori application, configure destinations, and deploy skills for real-time use within Work Zone.

With these steps, you empower users to interact with enterprise data and processes seamlessly using natural language—making your applications not just smarter, but more user-centric.

entry.title: An integrated view on Inbound Container Transport
entry.content:
Not too long ago, a client (a big shipper) lamented to me that it was so difficult to gain insight into the progress of the execution of procurement processes. When he ordered a container full of goods, he would, at best, receive a shipping notification with a container number and then have to search through the systems of various transporters to locate his cargo. In the worst case, he wouldn't hear anything more, and the goods would suddenly appear at the door of his warehouse. Or his container would be sitting in the port without his knowledge, and he would have to pay a significant amount in detention costs.

In my opinion, the greatest strength of SAP is not just the variety of features it offers to support business processes, but its ability to provide integrated process information. In the above case, this means that the purchaser should be able to track the progress and have all relevant of his of his shipment based on his purchase order number. And the transportation planner should be able to plan and communicate his cargo with the carrier using unique freight order numbers.

To demonstrate to this client that this is no longer futuristic, we put together the following demo, utilizing SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management (TM) and SAP Business Network for Freight Collaboration (FC), and SAP Business Network for Global Track and Trace (GTT), to show how it can support an inbound container transport from China to Europe.

This scenario begins with the creation of a Purchase Order with incoterms FOB at port of loading. In this case, the shipper plans and organizes its sea transport from the port of loading, (Guangzhou South China Oceangate), to the port of destination (Rotterdam), and from there, the road transport to the warehouse in Saarbrucken using SAP Transportation Management.

Based on the expected delivery date, the ocean transport is planned by selecting a departure/voyage from an ocean schedule. The freight booking is sent from SAP TM to the ocean carrier using the BN for FC network. Once confirmed by the ocean carrier, the transportation planner receives the result back in SAP TM

Based on the Freight booking, the progress of the execution process can be tracked in SAP GTT using updates from the ocean carrier or the visibility provider. To make this process more clear, we built a small low code tool for it in SAP Build, the GTT route simulator. I will elaborate on this in a later blog, but this is what it produces:

When the container is delivered to the port of Rotterdam, it is picked up by the road transporter, who confirms the order in FC, makes a dock appointment for the warehouse, and reports events in FC reporting. Arrival at the warehouse is registered in the gate-in process, after which the truck is assigned a dock, and the unloading and goods receipt take place. In the demo, this happens using Advanced Shipping & Receiving.

After the transport is completed, both the ocean carrier and the road carrier submit their invoices via BN for FC. If there are disputes, these are resolved through communication in BN for FC before a freight settlement document is created in Transportation Management, ensuring that the cumbersome process of PO reversal does not have to be initiated. The entire logistical process, from the FCL Purchase Order to the payment of the transporters, is transparent and integrated:

When I presented the demo to the client, one of the purchasers sighed, "It's so beautiful, I could almost cry." It was one of my more enjoyable days as a consultant.

entry.title: Partners expand Joule’s capabilities using custom Joule skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
In May 2025, SAP announced details about Joule Studio , a new capability within SAP Build for creating custom AI agents and skills powered by agentic AI. This feature allows customers and partners to develop and deploy tailored Joule agents and skills that automate workflows and enhance efficiency across both SAP and non-SAP systems.

To provide early exposure of this innovation to our partner ecosystem, a pilot edition of Hack2Build was launched for creating custom Joule skills. Selected partners received coaching and guidance while gaining access to the pre-General Availability phase of Joule Studio in SAP Build. These partners experimented with crafting custom Joule skills that could handle simpler, rule-based tasks to automate and streamline workflows. In this pilot edition, they were able to orchestrate and trigger these skills based on user intent using natural language inputs and integrate them seamlessly with both SAP and non-SAP systems. 

The Hack2Build initiative began on July 2nd with the selection of 12 partners based on their use case alignment with customer workflow needs, technical viability, expertise, and go-to-market strategies. This cross-functional collaboration involved teams from Joule Studio, SAP Build product engineering, Business AI Partner Management, SAP Industries & Experience, and Partner Ecosystem Success to drive innovations with our partners. The hack phase concluded on July 9th, 2025 with impressive showcases during the demo jam session.

Partners participate in the Hack2Build Pilot edition for custom Joule skills

Recently, SAP announced the general availability of Joule Studio in SAP Build. With Joule Studio  you can extend Joule’s out-of-the-box capabilities with company-specific skills.

Winners' Podium

During the Demo Jam event at our Hack2Build pilot initiative, an expert panel of judges reviewed each presentation to select four winners. In this post, we will highlight the custom Joule skills developed by these four winning partners, demonstrating their innovation and creativity in leveraging Joule Studio in SAP Build.

Hack2Build custom Joule skills, July 2-9, 2025 : Demo Jam Winners

 

cbs Corporate Business Solutions

AI-Driven Active Monitor (ADAM) designed by cbs simplifies interface monitoring within the SAP Integration Suite by making error messages which are cryptic, clearer and more actionable for IT and business users alike. By leveraging natural language interaction through SAP Joule, ADAM analyzes integration logs using comprehensive SAP knowledge, customer knowledge bases and resolves errors efficiently. The solution can be extended to handle recurring interface issues in Cloud Integration without manual intervention. Utilizing a combination of SAP Build, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model., Python services, and SAP HANA Cloud, ADAM offers real-time support and lowers costs by reducing manual checks and error resolution efforts.

AI-Driven Active Monitor (ADAM) by cbs

EY


EY TrueCost AI leverages custom Joule skills to help finance managers and stakeholders uncover hidden costs affecting profitability, such as rework, scrap or product returns. By analyzing SAP HANA data, it offers insights into indirect costs across procurement, operations, and logistics, empowering teams to proactively manage cost leakages. TrueCost AI combines business context with automation for real-time recommendations aligned with enterprise goals, enhancing decision-making and operational efficiency.

EY's TrueCost AI

 

All for One


All for One created a Joule skills-based maintenance assistant to support field technicians with AI-driven service workflows. Integrated with SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), the solution enables access to machine data, contract details and service history. Technicians use the All for One Equipment Viewer to identify faulty components, retrieve manuals and machine history through the All for One QuickGen RAG solution as well as initiate part orders via ticket creation. Joule skills support contract information retrieval and approval flows, reducing manual effort. This results in improved first-time fix rates and faster service delivery through a unified interface tailored for technician roles.  

 Sodales Solutions

Sodales demonstrated a streamlined incident management solution using custom Joule skills to improve regulatory compliance and enhance user experience. Custom Joule skill automates incident reporting by creating cases in real-time through SAP SuccessFactors HCM with Joule , integrated seamlessly with Sodales application via natural language chat interfaces. Leveraging the SAP Business Technology Platform components like SAP Build Work Zone and SAP HANA Cloud, it enhances operational efficiency for complex labor-intensive environments. By reducing manual input and improving data accuracy, this solution addresses critical incidents swiftly and precisely while laying groundwork for future AI-driven enhancements.

Automated Incident Case Creation by Sodales Solutions

Judges

The panel of judges devoted significant effort to evaluating the Demo Jam event. During this showcase, all the partners presented their custom Joule skills, demonstrating their custom Joule skills innovation and creativity.

  • Christian Pretzsch, Head of Joule, SAP Business AI Product Engineering
  • Hemant Rachh, Senior Director, Product Management, SAP Build
  • Kathrin Hettel, Vice President, Strategic Cross-Portfolio & AI Partnership
  • Pavel Penaz,  Global Vice President & Head of Portfolio - Ecosystem Readiness for SAP Business Suite

Special Thanks 

We extend our appreciation to the SAP team experts from Joule Studio and SAP Build Product Management, Business AI Partner Management, SAP Industries & Experiences and SAP Partner Excellence Center, who coached the partners to successfully develop their solutions during the Hack2Build pilot edition - custom Joule skills initiative. 

Next Phase 

Once Test, Demonstration, and Development Licenses become available, partners expect to complete their full-scope solutions based on experiences gained during the MVP development in the Hackathon phase. The SAP Partner Excellence Center will collaborate with all participating partners to support their journey toward a full-scale build and promote customer adoption.

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build – Part 4: Managing Access to Custom Joule Skills
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In the previous part of this series, we demonstrated how to build and deploy custom Joule Skills and integrate them into SAP Build Work Zone sites. However, a critical aspect of deploying these skills in a real-world environment is access control deciding who can use your custom skills and how to share them securely.

By default, only users who are explicitly granted Execute or Admin access in the shared environment can consume your deployed Joule Skills. If other users attempt to interact with the skill, they receive a generic fallback response from Joule, which doesn't reflect the actual skill functionality.

 

Let’s walk through how to share your Joule Skills securely and effectively using SAP Build and SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Understanding the Access Control Behaviour

SAP Build's environment sharing works as follows:

  • You can share a project with up to 10 user groups or 5 individual users.
  • You cannot mix individual users and groups; if you do, only groups will be considered.
  • The access types available are:
    • Execute – Allows users to use the deployed skill
    • Admin – Full access to manage the environment

Option 1: Open Access for Everyone

If your use case allows, you can make the skill available to all users within your organization:

  • Go to the shared environment in SAP Build.
  • Click on Share → Set General Access to Everyone with access: Execute.

 

This method makes the skill available to all users with access to the environment. Use with caution if the skill exposes sensitive operations or data.

Option 2: Controlled Access Using User Groups

For better governance and security, use user groups from your Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant:

  • Create a User Group in your IAS (Cloud Identity) tenant.

 

  • Assign the required users to this group (those who should have access to the skill).

 

  • In SAP Build, open the shared environment of your custom Joule Skill.

 

  • Click Share, set Type to User Group, and enter the exact name of the group you created in IAS.
  • Set the appropriate authorization (Execute or Admin).

 

Refresh & Redeploy Access

Once you’ve shared with user groups:

  • Navigate to the Joule tab inside the environment.
  • Click Refresh.

 

  • You’ll see a message: “Please redeploy the capability to refresh their access right.”
  • Click on “Click here to redeploy” to apply the new access configuration.

 

It may take a few minutes for the redeployment to complete. Use Refresh to monitor the status.

 

Final Verification

After successful redeployment:

  • The Launch button will become active again.

 

  • Users assigned to the user group can now consume the Joule Skill from the Work Zone site.
  • If any user still doesn’t see the expected response, try:
    • Clearing browser cookies
    • Using incognito/private mode for a fresh session

 

When users click Open from the response message, they will be directed to the associated application screen (if configured).

 

Conclusion

Access management is a vital step in rolling out custom Joule Skills at scale. Whether you want to expose your skill to all users or control access via user groups, SAP Build offers the flexibility to do both. Properly sharing and redeploying your skill ensures the right people get the right experience and keeps your environment secure and manageable.

entry.title: Enabling Joule Studio in SAP Build for existing Joule customers
entry.content:
Introduction

This post is intended for existing Joule customers who are looking to enable Joule Studio and start building custom Joule skills.

If you're enabling Joule for the first time—for example, with SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, or SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud—and want to activate Joule Studio alongside, we recommend starting with the Discovery Center mission: Establish a Unified Joule Instance. You should also check out the helpful blog series by my colleague @Diganta_Mandal, starting with Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.

On the other hand, if you’ve already enabled Joule with any of the SAP cloud solutions mentioned above and have an active Formation of type Integration with Joule (you can verify this in your BTP Global Account under System Landscape > Formations), then this blog will guide you through the steps to activate Joule Studio within your existing setup.


Motivation

We often receive questions from existing customers about how to enable Joule Studio. Some of the most common ones include:

  • Do we need to run the Joule booster again to enable Joule Studio in SAP Build?
  • Does SAP Build Process Automation need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance?

You’ll find answers to these and other key questions as you continue reading this blog post.

Prerequisites Before You Begin

  • Make sure your global account has the SAP Build entitlement, specifically the plan: build-default (Application).
  • Confirm that your SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant is included in your existing Formation.
  • Next, subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation with the plan: build-default (Application) in any subaccount of your choice. For guidance, refer to the Provisioning Setup section in Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio. Note: You can skip the Joule Booster step in this case.

Important: Joule Studio is not compatible with tenants using the SAP Build Process Automation (plan: standard). A new subscription using the build-default plan is required.

If your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant is not already part of your Formation and doesn't appear under System Landscape > Systems in your global account, you will need to manually add it.

Steps below for adding  SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your system landscape.

  1. Navigate to System Landscape > Systems and switch to the Service Owner View.









  2. Click on Add System and enter the details of your Cloud Identity Services tenant.


Steps to add SAP Build Process Automation in existing formation

  1. Go to your existing Formation of type Integration with Joule.

  2. Click Include Systems to launch the system inclusion wizard.
    Note: Your formation may already include systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public/Private Cloud, or other supported solutions.

    Answer to Question 1 (from the Motivation section):
    If Joule is already running with other solutions, you do not need to run the Joule Booster again to enable Joule Studio.


  3. In this example, a new subaccount named Joule Studio was created specifically for this purpose, with SAP Build Process Automation (plan: build-default) enabled in it.

    Answer to Question 2 (from the Motivation section):
    SAP Build Process Automation does not need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance.

  4. Select the Joule Studio subaccount and click Next Step.



  5. Choose Enable Capability Deployment, then proceed with Next Step.

  6. Review the summary and click Include.



    Your formation will begin synchronizing.



After a short while, if all steps have been completed successfully, the formation status will change to Ready.

You’re now set to start using Joule Studio to build and deploy your own custom Joule skills.



To continue, follow the next steps in the blog to:

  • Assign roles for Joule Skills developers. Refer Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.
  • Begin skill development using this blog post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 2: Developing and Deploying a Joule Skill

entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide — the first of a two-part series —We’ll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We’ll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we’ll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you’ll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click “Open in BTP Cockpit”.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you’ll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You’ll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 6 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won’t appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you’re ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent   
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we’re only creating Joule Skills in this post, we’ll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you’ll be taken to the Overview tab, where you’ll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click “Create”.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • Identifier: e.g., get-maintenance-order 
    • Description: e.g., get list of a maintenance order  
    • Click Create 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.  
  2. In the “General” tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter: 

➕Add Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: User query 
    • Description: Context for the endpoint to give the list of the orders 
    • Required: Unchecked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

➕Add Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name: List of Orders 
    • Type: Any 
    • List: Checked 
    • Required: Checked 
    • Description: List of orders depending on the user request (e.g., pending or open orders) 
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary — choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You’ve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ➕Plus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you’ll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it. 
  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query). 
  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API’s response schema. 
  5. Click End to configure the skill’s outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder  

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrders 

GET /MaintenanceOrder 

Retrieve all maintenance orders (can be filtered) 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

cGetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don’t need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value → A list of components (type: list) 
    • count → Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

  

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.  

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. “Show me all current maintenance orders” 
  2. “Get details for maintenance order 25” 
  3. “What operations are planned for maintenance order 4?” 
  4. “What is the description of material 19” 
  5. “How many units of material M-45678 are in stock?” 

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task — whether it’s fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we’ll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant — one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what’s blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life — stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Beginners: Everything You Need to Know - All at one stop!
entry.content:
This blog is for anyone in the SAP domain — from consultants to architects — who is curious about SAP Joule and wants to understand how it works. You're in the right place!

Disclaimer: This blog is based on publicly available information as of 24th July 2025, along with my personal interpretation. Sources of all referenced information, where available, are quoted in the REFERENCE section of this blog.

Topics covered in this blog are:

Welcome to the world of SAP Joule! Let's decode it into chunks! 

"How can I help you? 

Talk to me naturally. For example, 'What are my task for today?"

 

This is how Joule greets you in first place!

Joule — a name derived from the unit of energy — is here to energize our business processes, save valuable time, and simplify even the most tedious tasks resulting in greater efficiency and a noticeable uplift in the quality of our work.

SECTION 1: Understanding key terminologies and concepts:

Let’s cover some basic artificial intelligence terms before diving deeper into Joule for better understanding.

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that mimics human reasoning and behavior, enabling machines to make decisions on their own. By processing large volumes of data, AI can understand speech, identify patterns and trends, solve problems proactively, and forecast future outcomes.

  • GenAI also known as generative AI is a model where it can create new content which can either be text, image, audio and video based on the existing content that it already has.

  • LLM (Large language Model) is the specific model (like GPT, PaLM, LLaMA) that powers the text generation part of GenAI. It is a type of artificial intelligence model that is trained to understand and generate human-like language. It's designed to read, summarize, translate, predict, or generate text based on the input it receives. Eg, When we ask ChatGPT a question, it's an LLM that's interpreting our text and generating a relevant, natural-sounding response.

  • AI copilot is a virtual assistant that helps business application users complete tasks more easily through a conversational interface. It uses generative AI to understand requests, take actions, and offer insights from business data. AI Copilots use LLMs to understand natural language and assist users in real time.The answer that is provided to the user is limited to training data against LLMs. "Large" refers to the massive amount of data and the billions of parameters the model is trained on.

  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): In SAP world, customer specific data cannot be used to train the LLMs. And hence we need a better way to retrieve the desired outcomes without breaching the customer's data privacy. This is where RAG comes into picture. It is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). This is done through Document Grounding. As a part of preparation of RAG, it provided with SAP and customer specific documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are then chunked into smaller parts and are then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query. This information is passed to the LLM as prompts during runtime rather than getting it trained. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data. Rather, they get Grounded against customer specific data. 

  • HANA Vector Database enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords.

    Image source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uiv29xYlXvQ

  • For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. For instance, when a user asks about their company's paternity leave policy, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.

SECTION 2: What is SAP Joule and what are its use cases in the SAP world

SAP Joule is an AI copilot from SAP. Powered by SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), it serves as a virtual assistant that leverages generative AI to understand and respond to user requests within SAP systems.

Before diving deeper, Let's understand some of the use cases of SAP Joule. Below are some of the end-user prompts that can be sent to Joule, where it responds appropriately using natural language processing. These examples are sourced from SAP's official Joule product pages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html#agility-for-all

Why Joule?

Joule is SAP domain-specific and is integrated with SAP’s suite of products, ensuring seamless interaction and data exchange across the SAP portfolio. It is also a responsible AI solution, with a strong emphasis on industry-specific regulations and standards. As a result, Joule is a more Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible AI copilot for SAP.

As specified earlier, the LLMs in Joule are not actually trained to respond to SAP user queries. Instead, Joule use document grounding through RAGe (Retrieval-Augmented Generation for enterprise) for unstructured data, and the SAP Knowledge Graph for structured data, enabling it to provide more comprehensive responses by referencing business documents from both SAP and third-party repositories , while LLMs are used to add natural language rather than the actual context in the response that is sent to user by Joule. That is, Grounding uses a customer’s own knowledge sources (e.g., travel policies, enablement content, service manuals, FAQs, etc.) to supplement the capabilities of Large language models (LLMs). This gives Joule a unique understanding of SAP data and processes, allowing it to respond more reliably than any other AI copilot.

Joule is seamlessly integrated into various SAP cloud solutions to help users work more efficiently across different business functions, such as:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition

  • SAP SuccessFactors

  • SAP Ariba

  • SAP Sales Cloud

  • SAP Customer Experience solutions

  • SAP Concur

  • SAP ABAP Cloud

However, it is worth noting that Joule is not available for on-premise solutions.

Thus the main advantages of SAP Joule include:

  • Enhanced decision-making

  • Accelerated end-to-end business processes

  • Personalized UI with inherited user authorizations

  • Advanced analytics

  • Contextual awareness

  • Ability to meet diverse business needs

Business application supported by SAP Joule:

SAP Joule runs on the AI Foundation of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and supports a wide range of business application such as Finance, Procurement, Supply Chain, Human Resources, Sales and Services, Marketing and E-Commerce, Development, and Consulting.  Apart from some of the use cases described before, a detailed list of business use cases are available through URL => https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/use-cases.html

Joule's interaction pattern:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

Joule's interaction pattern can vary from:

  1. Informational: The Joule provides answers to factual questions (e.g. "What are the key rules for a team outing?")

  2. Navigational: The Joule guides users through a multi-step process or an internal journey, like approving a request or changing organizational data. (e.g. “Where in the app do I send a promotion request?”)

  3. Transactional: The Joule engages in task completion workflows, e.g. reviewing and updating position details (job title, department, cost center), then confirming by saying “Done”. It also supports user edits and next steps before finalizing. (e.g. “Update the position title to Sustainability Supply Chain Consultant — ready to submit?”)

  4. Analytical: The Joule offers data insights, metrics, and visual analytics, such as attrition trends vs. hiring rates charted by quarter. It helps users interpret numbers and trends. (e.g.“What was our quarterly attrition rate in 2024?”)

SECTION 3: Joule architecture

Image source: Joule learning journey 

Joule architecture consists of key components which work together to respond to a user's question.

  1. Scenario Catalog: The Scenario Catalog holds information about all the available scenarios, functions, and skills in SAP cloud applications. In helps to distinguish between different user questions and guides Joule to understand the request and connect it to the right action or system or workflow. This acts like a blueprint that maps user queries to the appropriate actions, destinations, or logic within SAP systems. For example, if a user query is "Retrieves the current leave balance for a given employee", then this gets mapped as below:
    1. Scenario: 'Get_Employee_Leave_Balance'
    2. Business application : Human Resource
    3. 'leave balance': Employee ID, leave Type and Date Range.
  2. Knowledge Catalog: This contains SAP-knowledge as well as the customer-owned knowledge. It is a collection of documents and content sources (often unstructured or semi-structured) that are made available to Joule for question-answering using RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) techniques. It supports Joule in answering open-ended, natural language questions that aren’t directly tied to structured data or APIs. For example, it can have a company's HR policies (e.g., leave, travel, benefits), Finance guidelines (e.g., expense reimbursement rules) and so on. These documents are chunked and vectorized using embeddings in HANA vector database as specified earlier. When a user asks a related question, Joule retrieves relevant chunks and sends them to the LLM to generate a grounded answer.
  3. User Context: This helps joule to contextualize a user's question. This includes information about the SAP cloud applications the user is currently using, along with any additional SAP applications the customer has licensed and activated for use with Joule. Joule also recognizes the user’s roles and permissions, ensuring they can access only the information or perform the actions they are authorized to within the SAP cloud environment. Additionally, Joule takes into account the user’s chat history and context to provide most relevant and accurate responses to user queries. To put in other words, a user will be able to view or perform any tasks only if they are authorized to do so based on their existing authorization. 
  4. Document Grounding: Large Language Models (LLMs) are generally capable of understanding prompts and generating human-like responses. However, they often lack the context and specificity needed for business scenarios. To address this, Joule uses a technique called document grounding. This allows Joule to generate more accurate and relevant responses by referencing business documents stored in SAP and third-party repositories. As part of document grounding, customers can upload their own content (such as HR policies, travel policies, service manuals, etc.). When an end user asks a question, Joule searches these documents for relevant information and returns a concise, natural-language response, including the source references. This ensures the answers are grounded in the customer's own structured and unstructured data, making them more trustworthy and context-aware.
  5.  Grounding: This is the process of combining generative LLMs with advanced information retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy and relevance of responses—without the need to train or fine-tune the model on company-specific data. It leverages a customer’s internal knowledge sources (e.g., policies, FAQs, training material) to supplement the LLM’s existing knowledge. This improves the model’s reliability and ensures that responses reflect the customer’s unique business context.
  6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). As part of the RAG, Document Grounding is performed. In this step, RAG is provided with relevant documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are chunked into smaller parts and then embedded into dense, continuous vectors—known as embeddings—which represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query.
  7.  HANA Vector Database: It enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords. For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. When a user asks about their leave balance, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.
  8.  Knowledge Graph: This graph is a semantic network that connects entities (like customers, products, orders, employees, etc.) and defines how they are related. This helps Joule go beyond keyword matching or document lookup. It actually lets Joule "understand" business context and structure.  Joule uses the graph to understand how different entities are linked (e.g., “Employee X belongs to Department Y” or “Invoice A is tied to Purchase Order B”). With this, Joule disambiguate questions and provide more accurate answers.  It also enables logical inferences, like “Show me all open invoices for suppliers in Germany”, “List products related to a delayed shipment” etc. Even if the data is spread across multiple systems, the graph can link them together efficiently.

 

 

Image sources: Knowledge Graph or Vector Database… Which is Better? and  GraphRAG: The Marriage of Knowledge Graphs and RAG: Emil Eifrem

NOTE: While RAG brings in document-based context and vector search finds the right text chunks, the Knowledge Graph brings in structure and relationship-based logic. Eg: RAG may find a document about a purchase policy, but the Knowledge Graph helps determine which department owns that policy and who can approve it.

Does LLM gets trained with SAP's data?

When SAP’s AI assistant Joule interacts with a Large Language Model (LLM), it doesn’t send data for storage or training. Instead, it shares information only briefly, as part of a prompt during runtime. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time, but it doesn’t remember or learn from what it receives. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data.

Joule's orchestration layer:

Image source: Examining how to onboard and extend Joule | AI105

Steps involved within Joule for processing user query:

  1. User submits query in natural language via Joule client in SAP cloud apps
  2. The prompt is sent to the Dialogue Management system, which manages the conversation flow and understands the user's intent.
  3. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) service forms a semantic vector search query based on the user input.
